sub_topic: Finding the derivative of a function
message_1: Find the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 8x^3 + 6x^2 - 2x + 9 at x = 2.
message_2:
To find the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 8x^3 + 6x^2 - 2x + 9, we will first find the derivative of each term with respect to x, and then evaluate the derivative at x = 2.

The derivative of f(x) with respect to x is:

f'(x) = d(3x^4)/dx - d(8x^3)/dx + d(6x^2)/dx - d(2x)/dx + d(9)/dx

Using the power rule (d(x^n)/dx = nx^(n-1)):

f'(x) = 12x^3 - 24x^2 + 12x - 2

Now, we will evaluate the derivative at x = 2:

f'(2) = 12(2)^3 - 24(2)^2 + 12(2) - 2
f'(2) = 12(8) - 24(4) + 24 - 2
f'(2) = 96 - 96 + 24 - 2
f'(2) = 22

So, the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 8x^3 + 6x^2 - 2x + 9 at x = 2 is 22.
